title: Which presidential candidate will win Florida?
preds: Looks like numerous questions have been resurrected.
Congrats to people who got this one.
The DNC did not dominate the urban areas as they have in other states.

So.... how does that 538 31% chance feel now? Lol Question everything the mainstream media has told you (or not told you ((Hunter's laptop))) for 4 years. Busy makin' crow cakes... makin' cakes... makin' cakes...

Daaaaaaaaaaang! That mail in lead juuuuuust about dwindled to nothing, eh?!? 104k? Awww buddy! Got this one won. R's gonna rock it out today. "Democrats holding a lead of roughly 100,000 votes over Republicans. However, the gap between the two parties has narrowed significantly in the state, raising alarm bells for Democrats. 
Over a million Democrats cast mail-in ballots in the state two weeks ago, prior to the start of early voting, when Democrats led Republicans by 462,000 ballots."
https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/524085-unprecedented-early-voting-gives-democrats-hope-while-republicans-count-on

[Post-mortem two days after election: I screwed up by putting too much confidence in pollsters, who missed the big hispanic swing toward Donald Trump. Bad data input = flawed output in a model.] Pulling this back to 80%, still don't have a handle on how many will turnout tomorrow. But right now Biden is going into election day leading by about 340,000 votes or 3.8 percentage points. The math, based on the polling crosstabs reported on Twitter, is as follows:
3,512,211 Democratic votes * .91 = 3,196,112 Biden votes cast by Democratic voters
3,512,211 Democratic votes * .07 = 245,855 Trump votes cast by Democratic voters
3,404,088 Republican votes * .09 = 306,368 Biden votes cast by Republican voters
3,404,088 Republican votes * .89 = 3,029,638 Trump votes cast by Republican voters
1,933,648 NPA votes *.49 = 947,488 Biden votes cast by NPA voters
1,933,648 NPA votes *.43 = 831,469 Trump votes cast by NPA voters 5,090,731 registered voters in FL haven't voted yet. Of those:
1,619,584 registered Democrats haven't voted yet.
1,616,111 registered Republicans haven't voted yet.
1,719,398 registered with NPA haven't voted yet. It's a big gap that Trump needs to make up, but there's also the potential for a huge Republican turnout tomorrow.
Biden looks poised to win here with a huge vote advantage going into tomorrow, Turnout for Republicans will have to be sky high to overcome it.
Trump has an extremely strong base.
Looks like it could be a real tossup
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Mail ballots piling up in Florida post station, are there more in florida?

As expected, early voting has slowed in the past couple of days, advantaging Democrats, since the yet-to-vote registered voters skew highly Republican according to polls. Although the lead has narrowed, Biden still appears to me to be up by about 10 points going into the final GOP voting surge.  There's a bit of a fallacy I see in some articles about Florida, assuming that No Party Affiliation voters will go 50/50 Trump/Biden and that crossover voting rates will be the same for Republicans as they are for Democrats. This is not supported by polling.  Bumping this up to 85% Biden, based on the data. The 15% comes from percentage chance of polling error, various FL shenanigans by the usual suspects, and massive GOP turnout on election day.

Biden is actually polling very well in the state right now while Trump has taken a recent nose dive. It's by no means a sure thing but given that Trump needs Florida and has campaigned hard there, Biden really couldn't ask for a better lead in to Election Week.

Republicans are turning out in high numbers in early voting. They have a lead in in-person early voting in Miami-Dade, a county Hillary won with over 60%. Democrats went into the 2016 election with a 95K advantage in early voting, but Trump ended up winning the state. As of today, the Democrat lead stands at 131K in early vote count. Republicans reduce the lead by 40K each day. Hillary's support among Hispanics in Florida was 27 pts higher than Trump. Biden only has a 5 pt advantage.  Trump wins the state by 2-3%. 
https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/29/miami-voter-turnout-democrats-433643
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
It may be my wishful thinking...

Marist College poll, A+ rated pollster by 538, just came out with Biden +4 in likely voters. 
http://maristpoll.marist.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/NBC-News_Marist-Poll_FL-Likely-Voters_NOS-and-Tables_202010281159.pdf
Among those who have already voted, page 9 of that PDF, Biden is 59% compared with 40% for Trump. Using the vote count on October 27th (a conservative estimate since some mailed-in ballots were en route), as of that date there was a cumulative total of about 3.8 million ballots cast for Biden and 2.6 million for Trump. In the 2 days since then, 980,000 additional votes have been cast in FL. Using the yet-to-vote percentages from the poll, about 363k of those votes were for Biden and 568k were for Trump. My current estimated vote tally for ballots already submitted is:
Biden 4.1 million
Trump 3.1 million. For each million extra ballots cast after that October 27th date of the poll, Trump should get 580,000 votes and Biden 370,000. (At some point, I wonder if Republicans will realize that their undemocratic quest to stop counting late-arriving ballots is actually hurting them, not Democrats, this year, since Dems got the message to get their votes in early.) How much runway is there for Trump to catch up? There are 1.8 million absentee ballots yet to be returned. There are about 5 million registered voters left who have not yet voted nor have requested an absentee ballot.  Total: 6.8 million if everyone voted who is registered to do so. For Trump to win at this point, it would require maybe 4.8 million more votes to be cast from now until election day, for an overall turnout of 87% of FL's registered voters.  The Marist poll estimates 74% as likely voters in its sample (page 2). For historical context, in 2016 75% of FL's registered voters turned out, and the record was 83% in 1992.
Biden looks to win here but it could be close due to Cubans voting for Trump en masse.

Did some quick 'n dirty math based on the latest Yougov poll conducted through October 23, which thankfully broke out the numbers based on who had already voted (61% Biden, 37% Trump, 2% other as of that date), I came up with Biden having a lead of a little more than 800,000 votes currently, out of 6.6 million cast. The lead is shrinking each day, since Trump led 57% to 41% among those who had not yet voted. Democrats at this point should actually root for those GOP lawyers, politicians, and Supreme Court Justices who are trying to stop the late-arriving ballots from being counted. This is one of the big ironies of 2020.

- Good early voting and vote by mail numbers for Biden
- High voter turnout
- Always a cliffhanger
- Higher vote-by-mail ballots rejextion

Back up as evidence suggests seniors are less than impressed with DT

Since the debate, Biden's lead over Trump has increased in virtually every poll. Trump getting the virus, then telling seniors it wasn't dangerous, and insistence on promising healthcare without providing any details are likely a few of the reasons his support is diminishing in the state. It's definitely not solid blue, but its gotten to the point where its nearly leaning Dem, which was almost unthinkable a few weeks ago. It will almost definitely be close, but Dems already have hundreds of thousands more mail-in ballots submitted than Reps and with just three weeks left until the election it's hard to justify not giving Biden the advantage here.

Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 47% for trump to Biden's 48.9%. Seven day momentum was in Biden's favor, improving his position by 0.3%.

If you forget the history, FL is not actually a close one right now:
1) Dems massively ahead in early voting: https://twitter.com/KevinCate/status/1314552848122892290 Almost 1.5 million votes already cast
2) Lots of independents have voted already too, which matters because...
3) Biden has significant lead in the polling average: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/florida/ At this point Trump has to massively turn things around to make up for the fact that so many Floridians have already voted. Simple math. There is zero issue of pretending the mail-in ballots are "rigged" in FL or stopping the counting, because the ballots are being counted as they are received. This is not Pennsylvania.

Several rapidly changing variables make this a photo finish.  E.g. at least 10,000 ex felons allowed to vote.  Over 150K new registered R and D with more Rep being registered.  Likely record voter turnout, with (IMHO) more increase D turnout than increase in Rep turnout.  Hispanic vote being fought over and their turnout is usually low and will likely be much higher now.  I have no confidence of what will happen except that it will be within 1% of the total vote.

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

Biden's lead has decreased to less than 2 points in Florida, which is not much better than a toss-up. With only one month before election day (give or take) this contest will likely remain a close one and may be one of the last called after all the votes are in. Rumblings of a 2000 style win for the Reps are coming in hot and heavy online but there is still a chance Biden can win the state so long as he has effective voter turnout and does not concede prior to the tallies being called.

Trump now over the margin of error on the only poll that got 2016 right. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2018/11/10/pollster_who_got_it_right_in_2016_does_it_again_138621.html
"Cahaly managed to pick up support for Trump that all other pollsters missed by employing a unique method that sought to measure support from voters who'd been “inactive” in recent election cycles, as well as adding a question to his surveys designed to isolate the effect of social desirability bias among Trump voters – the concept that people won’t tell pollsters their true intentions for fear of being stigmatized or being politically incorrect. After asking voters who they were supporting in 2016, the pollster followed up by asking them who they thought their neighbors were supporting, Trump or Clinton. Cahaly consistently found a high degree of variance between who respondents said they were voting for and who they thought their neighbors were voting for, suggesting there was in fact a “shy Trump effect” at play."

Polling from 2016 was notoriously inaccurate and 2020 polling reflects the same "data". With no legitimate third party already polling well and many states closed to new entry to their ballots, a third party is out of the question. Respective speeches from the democratic candidate and the republican candidate on independence day demonstrate two opposed forms of rhetoric. The republican rhetoric is proud of american ideals and the democratic rhetoric is weak, whinging, and critical. No matter how correct people may think democratic points are, the truth is that rhetoric is a stronger determiner of political outcomes. Today it as true as it was in Teddy Roosevelt's 1910 speech, it's not the critic who counts. However, the power of outrage peddlers cannot be overlooked. Funding streams of leftist agencies like BLM, when focused on one candidate, could make the difference and forces me to hedge at a high rate.

Governor also seems hell-bent on voter suppression more generally. So although the polls look favorable for Biden, I fear many potential voters will be unable to cast a ballot.

Coronavirus impacts on the I-4 corridor both for public health and the economy will  likely be peaking in October. This will likely swing voters toward Biden who will be viewed as our best chance to get out of this mess. South Florida is already extremely angered by the botched response and the rural areas do not have enough population to make up the difference. Also, moderates and liberals are more likely to opt for mail in ballots due to health concerns, while conservatives may be less likely due to the Presidents claims regarding the issue.

The Olde Folkes of Florida seem to be leaning against the idea that they should die in order to support the economy for a pair of increasingly irrational Republican officeholders.   The Cuban vote is increasingly lukewarm toward politicians who carry on about Cuba, because they are now third generation US citizens and quite comfy here; they are instead becoming somewhat reluctant to sacrifice their parents and grandparents in The Current Emergency.  The tree-hugger vote is growing some as Miami Beach is awash much of the year and the 'Glades are disappearing and the spiders are getting bigger.  Even up north in Honorary Georgia, some folks have figured out that they are not getting much out of The Current Incumbent.   Lots of these groups may not turn out to vote for Biden, but they are much more likely than formerly to refrain from voting at all.  And as I try to remind such people, if you don't vote, my vote counts twice.
Voter breakdown/demographics  are favorable to POTUS.  The divides within the Hispanic population are significant.

Trump carried Florida over Hillary 49.0% to 47,8% in 2016. A close thing but I ask myself what has changed since then that may drive the vote?  Florida will be hit hard by COVID-19 economically because it is a tourist state. The tourism workers out of work will see Trump as more likely to bring the economy back. Biden does little to inspire confidence regarding fixing or growing the economy. In the end, its like Bill Clinton said about all elections "It's the economy stupid." Hillary ignored this and it cost her. Biden has the same weakness. He presents no compelling plan. This is the big vote driver. Florida is state full of old people. Old people like Trump. Old people turn out to vote. One wild card is that old people may fear COVID-19 exposure and stay home. To avoid repeating the Hillary vote profile, Biden needs to get a better turn out with the young and the black voters. Black voters are currently energized and this will help unless the anger dies down. Biden does not naturally appeal to blacks (like Obama or Bill Clinton) any more than Hillary did. A black VP might help unless it is Kamela because I think black people really don't like her). As far as the young are concerned, they are unreliable and unpredictable. I say they don't show up. I say the black vote disappoints also like with Hillary. Lots of people are tired of Trump but Biden just looks tired and worn out. Voting for Biden is like buying a used car with 300,000 miles on it. In the end jobs drive the vote. Trump looks better for jobs. Trump squeaks out a win in Florida again.

The loyal Trump voters will vote for him no matter what.  Moderates will vote against him this time.  The young vote might actually turn out now because of George Floyd, if they remember in November.  The only problem bringing out the democratic vote is Biden doesn't bring great enthusiasm.  My bet on swing voters going dem this time around.

Anti trump vote will be strong everywhere. It’s underestimated, I think, in general.   The pathetic response To Covid-19 we’re witnessing from the current administration and the damages done to the economy because of this late and weak response will certainly damage the republican party’s chances nationwide with moderates who usually decide these things. I don’t trust the masses to wear masks and distance either, so the virus will in no way look like it’s under control in early November.  We will likely still see double digit unemployment as well which won’t work well for the trump administration. If we don’t feel safe, we don’t spend money... we don’t travel, eat out, or even care about a new car when we can’t use it...or feel we can afford it once the stock markets get a grip on reality, and our 401k’s are taking the hit that’s likely coming.  If we don’t have the money, we can’t spend it, and hiring back all of the recently unemployed is just not going to be something that happens soon enough for impatient Americans. Thousands of small businesses are going under, and won’t be hiring back, even more will not be back to the levels of hiring pre-virus. You need fewer waiters when capacity is at 50%... and restaurants can’t survive long at all under these restraints.  Adding it all up, if the vote happened today I believe Dems barely win, and in November it’s likely to be more of a mandate.  Add the civil unrest to the equation, and viola!, Again, moderates have reason to vote against trump. His Law and order message we don’t need more of. We need leadership that actually listens, and understands that science is a better predictor than gut feelings, and changing the way we police is a priority for us all. Police are not social workers, yet they are asked to respond to those issues when in no way are they trained for it. Our judicial system and Republicans are losing the arguments that matter most to the electorate, and it’s the trump administration putting fuel to a fire that needs to be put out.  Add to this the fact that the majority of the wealth in the country is in the hands of baby boomers who are being told appropriately to stay home. Hard to spend your retirement money only on Amazon... One last thing I see happening is the youth vote that Bernie had going will shift to Biden in a big way.   What I saw today on Fox News was pure propaganda that the youth isn’t going to buy. Defunding police movement is an issue being championed by this same group that did not turn out for the dems in 2016. They will likely vote for Biden.
The older population and hispanic population that went for Trump in 2016 will turn on him in a big way in 2020.

The level of divisiveness and animosity across the US will continue to grow as COVID continues to upend the normal social order. As the percentage of hospitalizations increases, overwhelming health systems and continuing to crash the economy, the unwillingness of citizens to take steps to protect themselves from spreading or contracting the virus will cause further divisions, and the president will ultimately take the blame. Additionally, his increasingly divisive position on COVID and race relations is going to bring the “silent majority” back to the polls.  However, the uncertainty of the method of voting (in person vs. mail in) may skew this unpredictably. With a republican governor who is a vocal acolyte for the president, I believe significant effort will be made to suppress mail in balloting.  Finally, Biden continues to fail to inspire enthusiasm, which likely means the driver for Democrats and independents to vote will have to be a desire to replace Trump. Undecided Republicans could just stay home or not bother to vote, then blame the continued presidency on democrats failing to vote.

Florida has voted for the Presidential winner in every election since 1928 except for two elections in 1960 and 1992 - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellwether#States   (2016 - 1928)/4 + 1 = 23 Presidential Elections
21/23 = 91.3% = Florida Winner is the US Presidential Winner. Unlike Ohio I see no reason to suggest that Florida has lost its status as a bellwether state for US Presidential Elections and therefore will assume it remains so for the 2020 US Presidential Election. In a different forecast I gave Joe Biden = 78%, Donald Trump = 22% and Someone Else = 0% of winning the US Presidency in 2020. Using these percentages I give -
Democratic Candidate Winning Florida = 73% = 78*.913 + 22*(1-.913)
Republican Candidate Winning Florida = 27% = 22*.913 + 78*(1-.913)
Someone Else Winning Florida = 0%
